prompt: Extract all entities of the following text and represent it in a table format. \\nBut no county in Pennsylvania \u2013 and maybe in the country \u2013 is as consistently swingy as Erie County, which includes the city of Erie, the fourth-largest in the state. Since 2008, Pennsylvania has held 25 statewide elections \u2013 for president, senator, governor, attorney general, treasurer and auditor. In 23 of those 25 elections \u2013 92% of the time \u2013 Erie County voted for the winner. And voters in the county didn\u2019t simply back one party. They voted for 20 Democratic candidates and five Republican candidates, including Trump for president, Pat Toomey for senator and Tom Corbett for governor. The only times Erie County voted the \u201cwrong\u201d way were in 2010, when Democratic Senate candidate Joe Sestak won the county but lost statewide to Toomey, and in 2020, when Democratic candidate for treasurer Joe Torsella won Erie County but narrowly lost statewide to Republican Stacy Garrity.
response:
| Entity | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Pennsylvania | State in the United States |
| Erie County | County located in Pennsylvania |
| Erie | City located in Erie County, Pennsylvania |
| Statewide elections | Elections held for statewide offices such as President, Senator, Governor, Attorney General, Treasurer, and Auditor in Pennsylvania |
| 25 elections | Total number of statewide elections held in Pennsylvania from 2008 to 2023 |
| 23 elections | Number of times Erie County voted for the winner in these 25 elections |
| 92% | Percentage of times Erie County voted for the winner in these 23 elections |
| Democratic candidates | Candidates who ran for office as members of the Democratic Party |
| Republican candidates | Candidates who ran for office as members of the Republican Party |
| Joe Sestak | Democratic candidate for Senate in 2010 |
| Pat Toomey | Republican candidate for Senate in 2010 |
| Tom Corbett | Republican candidate for Governor in 2010 |
| Joe Torsella | Democratic candidate for Treasurer in 2020 |
| Stacy Garrity | Republican candidate for Treasurer in 2020 |

prompt: Extract 4 keywords of the following content: We propose Generation-Augmented Retrieval (GAR) for answering open-domain questions, which augments a query through text generation of heuristically discovered relevant contexts without external resources as supervision. We demonstrate that the generated contexts substantially enrich the semantics of the queries and GAR with sparse representations (BM25) achieves comparable or better performance than state-of-the-art dense retrieval methods such as DPR. We show that generating diverse contexts for a query is beneficial as fusing their results consistently yields better retrieval accuracy. Moreover, as sparse and dense representations are often complementary, GAR can be easily combined with DPR to achieve even better performance. GAR achieves state-of-the-art performance on Natural Questions and TriviaQA datasets under the extractive QA setup when equipped with an extractive reader, and consistently outperforms other retrieval methods when the same generative reader is used.", "category

Extract keywords from this text:\\n\\nBlack-on-black ware is a 20th- and 21st-century pottery tradition developed by the Puebloan Native American ceramic artists in Northern New Mexico. Traditional reduction-fired blackware has been made for centuries by pueblo artists. Black-on-black ware of the past century is produced with a smooth surface, with the designs applied through selective burnishing or the application of refractory slip. Another style involves carving or incising designs and selectively polishing the raised areas. For generations several families from Kha'po Owingeh and P'ohwh\u00f3ge Owingeh pueblos have been making black-on-black ware with the techniques passed down from matriarch potters. Artists from other pueblos have also produced black-on-black ware. Several contemporary artists have created works honoring the pottery of their ancestors.
response:
* Puebloan Native American
* ceramic artists
* Northern New Mexico
* reduction-fired blackware
* pottery tradition
* Kha'po Owingeh
* P'ohwh\u00f3ge Owingeh
* pueblos
* matriarch potters
* ancestors
* contemporary artists
